SEARCH
Package textui.element

Class Element

java.lang.Object
textui.element.Element
Direct Known Subclasses:
TextElement
public class Element extends Object
Represents a UI element that can be rendered as text on a screen.

An Element has configurable dimensions, padding, margin, border, and display properties. It supports nesting child elements and can render itself and its children according to different display modes (BLOCK, INLINE, FLEX).

Elements manage their own text content and visual layout constraints such as min/max width and height, alignment, and fill behavior.

Note: Some properties (e.g., padding, margin, display) cannot be changed once children are added to the element.

  • Field Details

    • border

      protected Border border
      The border configuration for this element, indicating which sides have borders. Defaults to no borders on any side.

    • padding

      protected Padding padding
      The padding inside the element, specifying space between content and border. Initialized with zero padding on all sides.

    • margin

      protected Margin margin
      The margin outside the element, specifying space between this element and others. Initialized with zero margin on all sides.

    • display

      protected Display display
      The display mode for this element, determining layout behavior of its children. Defaults to BLOCK display.

    • justifyContent

      protected FlexAlign justifyContent
      The alignment of child elements along the main axis (justify-content). Defaults to FLEX_START (start-aligned).

    • alignItems

      protected FlexAlign alignItems
      The alignment of child elements along the cross axis (align-items). Defaults to FLEX_START (start-aligned).

    • fill

      protected boolean fill
      Whether the element should fill its available space. Defaults to false.

    • height

      protected int height
      The current height of the element, including content and spacing. Defaults to 0.

    • width

      protected int width
      The current width of the element, including content and spacing. Defaults to 0.

    • minHeight

      protected int minHeight
      The minimum allowed height of the element. Defaults to 0.

    • minWidth

      protected int minWidth
      The minimum allowed width of the element. Defaults to 0.

    • maxHeight

      protected int maxHeight
      The maximum allowed height of the element. Defaults to Integer.MAX_VALUE (no maximum).

    • maxWidth

      protected int maxWidth
      The maximum allowed width of the element. Defaults to Integer.MAX_VALUE (no maximum).

    • heightSet

      protected boolean heightSet
      Indicates if the height has been explicitly set by the user. Defaults to false.

    • widthSet

      protected boolean widthSet
      Indicates if the width has been explicitly set by the user. Defaults to false.

    • childElements

      protected List<Element> childElements
      The list of child elements contained within this element. Initially empty.

    • screen

      protected List<List<Character>> screen
      The 2D screen buffer representing the rendered characters of this element. Each inner list is a row of characters.

  • Constructor Details

    • Element

      public Element()
      Default constructor. Initializes an Element with no explicit size set.

    • Element

      public Element(int size)
      Constructs a square Element with given size for both height and width. Marks height and width as explicitly set.
      Parameters:
      size - the height and width to set for this element

    • Element

      public Element(int height, int width)
      Constructs an Element with the specified height and width. Marks height and width as explicitly set.
      Parameters:
      height - the height of the element
      width - the width of the element

      Returns:
      true if the element fills its container; false otherwise

      the calculated height of the element

    • getScreen

      public List<List<Character>> getScreen()
      Returns the current screen buffer of the element as a list of rows of characters. This method triggers a printScreen call to update the screen before returning it.
      Returns:
      the screen buffer as a list of character rows

    • getWidth

      public int getWidth()
      Returns the total width of this element, including padding, margin, and border. The returned width is constrained between the minimum and maximum width limits.
      Returns:
      the total width of the element

    • setDisplay

      public Element setDisplay(Display display) throws ValueCannotBeSetException
      Sets the display mode of this element.
      Parameters:

      Returns:
      this element instance for chaining
      Throws:

    • addBorder

      protected void addBorder()
      Adds borders to the element's screen buffer based on the border settings. Calls the respective methods to add top, right, bottom, and left borders if they are enabled in the border property.

    • getElementHeight

      protected int getElementHeight()
      Calculates the effective height of this element, considering its own size and the layout of its child elements according to the display mode. If the height is manually set (heightSet == true), returns the set height. If the display mode is INLINE, delegates to getElementHeightInline(). If the display mode is FLEX, returns the maximum height among children. If the display mode is BLOCK, returns the sum of all children heights. The returned height is clamped between the element's minHeight and maxHeight.
      Returns:
      The calculated height of the element.

    • getElementHeightInline

      protected int getElementHeightInline()
      Calculates the height of this element when the display mode is INLINE. The height is calculated by fitting children horizontally up to maxWidth, wrapping to new rows as needed. The height of each row is the largest child height in that row. The total height is the sum of all row heights. If maxWidth is -1 (no max width), the height is the maximum child height.
      Returns:
      The calculated height when using INLINE display.

    • getElementWidth

      protected int getElementWidth()
      Calculates the effective width of this element, considering its own size and the layout of its child elements according to the display mode. If the width is manually set (widthSet == true), returns the set width. If the display mode is BLOCK, the width is the maximum width among children. Otherwise (e.g., INLINE or FLEX), the width is the sum of all child widths. The returned width is clamped between the element's minWidth and maxWidth.
      Returns:
      The calculated width of the element.

    • insertChild

      public Element insertChild(Element child) throws ChildrenNotAllowedException
      Inserts a single child element into this element's children list.
      Parameters:
      child - the child element to insert
      Returns:
      this element instance for chaining
      Throws:
      ChildrenNotAllowedException - if this element does not allow children

    • insertChildren

      public Element insertChildren(List<Element> children) throws ChildrenNotAllowedException
      Inserts multiple child elements into this element's children list.
      Parameters:
      children - the list of child elements to insert
      Returns:
      this element instance for chaining
      Throws:
      ChildrenNotAllowedException - if this element does not allow children

    • printScreen

      public Element printScreen()
      Renders the element's content onto its screen representation, including borders and child elements according to the display mode. The method resets the current screen, adds borders, and then adds child elements using the appropriate layout method based on the element's display property:
      • Display.BLOCK uses block layout
      • Display.INLINE uses inline layout
      • Display.FLEX uses flex layout
      Returns:
      this element instance for chaining

    • resetScreen

      protected void resetScreen()
      Resets the screen buffer to an empty state based on the current element size. This method clears the current screen content and reinitializes it as a 2D list of characters with dimensions equal to the element's height and width. Each cell is filled with '#' if the fill flag is true; otherwise, it is filled with a space character ' '. The screen acts as a visual buffer representing the element's rendering area.
